editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.name: Melina Yeh

respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: As it was presented by her majesty's servants, at the private house in Drury lane.
Printed for Andrew Crooke, and are to be sold at the castle gate in Dublin. 1640.

div.head: To my truly noble, and my ever honoured friend, captain Richard Owen.
div.p: This poem, at my return with you, from another kingdom (Wherein I enjoyed, as your employments would permit, the happiness of your knowledge, and conversation) emergent from the press, and prepared to seek entertainment abroad, I took boldness thus far to direct to your name and acceptance; promised by my confidence in your love to poesy, wherein your clear judgement and excellent abilities would at first have made me less adventurous. Be pleased till time mature a worthy satisfaction to your favours, to smile upon this tender of my gratitude, and while your services call you hence to enlarge your honour, by making your faith and valour more exemplary against a rebellious enemy, let me preserve a peace at home, in the contemplation of your friendship, and be happy to profess myself

closer.signed: Your humble servant and honoror, Ia. Shirley.

div.head: Scene 1.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Expect me an hour hence, my friend and I
Will walk and see the city, make it your
Care to get supper ready.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: If I do not
I know who's like to fare the worse.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: And be not
Drunk sirrah at our return.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: Yes I do use
To be drunk before you often.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: About your business:
And how dost like the town, and situation.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Trouble me not to answer ▪ such dull questions,
I see never a handsome girl yet, not a piece
Of a bonaroba; and the Duchess hold
But the complexion of those we ha' seen,
I wonot be corrupted with the palace
To be her bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: You'll change opinion;
Perhaps we ha' seen none but the rubbish, yet
there may be beauty's signior will tempt
Your most fastidious appetite, I fear
I shall have much ado to stave thee from 'em,

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: To quit that fear let's leave the city instantly;
The meal wonot digest women, I eat in't.
Not stave me from 'em?
We are for the wars;
This town will turn my blood, I wonot give
A Julio for my courage in twelve hours,
Unless they tie their women up.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Thou hast,
A mind to show thou canst be satire, patience
But till tomorrow and we'll hence.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Sir, let my heart present your welcome home,
You've been too long a stranger, I am happy
To embrace you again.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Me, meaning me, d'ye know me?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I hope you are not jealous of my friendship,
I thought our familiarity before
The sad misfortune came that made you banish
Yourself from Urbin had possessed you thoroughly,
How firm I dare be to you.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Dost thou know him? I ne'er saw his eyes before
To my best memory, are you not mistaken.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Perhaps in your affection which no art
Hath ever made me guilty to deserve,
I never did betray my friend to make you
Affect these clouds, but be it so.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: There is
But one half hour added to our ages
Since first we saw the city.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: In good time.
I will be bold to acquaint some bawd else
In whom you have more faith.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Is not the gentleman o'th to sides on's wits?
What did he call you.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Nay I know not, he
Said we had been familiar, in his dream sure,
For waking I ne'er saw him.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: You should have asked his name.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: To what purpose prithee. Enter Pietro.
Why does that gentleman stare upon us so.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Are you returned, this is confidence
You may repent.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: One has some need, you're welcome signior to Urbin.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Thank you, what's your name I pray.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: If you ha' forgotten mine, I remember Borgia.
A friend of yours, desires but to renew
Acquaintance w'ye.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Jigs, shall I after him and knock
Him o'er the pate.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: For looking on's
So scurvily.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: That may be dangerous,
Did he not name Borgia.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: But whether
He meant himself or you I understand not.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: He might as well ha' called me Bethlem Gabor;
Let's walk on still.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Ha Borgia, 'tis he, my noble friend returned,
Welcome, a thousand welcomes in thy bosom;
Why do you wear this strangeness in your face,
Can a few years render me lost to Borgia.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Sure he does call me Borgia.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Thou wert
Unkind in thy departure, with what devotion
could I have been a partner in thy travel
And have unequal fortune, being absent
Why was not I summoned to wait upon thee
In any part o'th world, but again welcome,
When arrived ye.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: I am very likesome body,
They all mistake me thus, we ha' seen no friends since.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I am your servant, thy unexpected sight
Will glad Mercutio's heart, your noble father
Who hath long mourned your absence.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Good old man,
He will rejoice to see him here no doubt on't.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: You have lost an uncle, but all his estate
Your father is possessed of.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: His age
Was fit for heaven, his wealth is added to
Your fathers to make yours the greater fortune.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Pardon noble friend,
I was persuaded time and absence had
Wrought such a change upon my face, that no man
Would know me again, but though I may to some
Appear a stranger, I must stand discovered
To a friend's penetrating eye, again
Possessed your faithful servant, what's my name.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: Shall I wait on you to your father sir.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: What were I best to do.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Your sisters grown a gallant gentlewoman,
The only beauty of Urbin, and waits on
The Duchess, her soft lips will seal your welcome.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: He does but jest, they are all witches here.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: No more jeers ▪
Go or be lame for ever.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Is she grown
Worthy that hour you express, and has
The Duchess taken her to grace.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: 'Tis more than whispered,
The favourite loves her.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: He that was cause
Of your remove Ursini.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Cry you mercy,
I know him well enough; but does he love her?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: You will be tripping,
Your own heels up.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Let me alone
To remember her, Cornelia for more
Security, I'll put her in my table book.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: There is no lady in the preserves
A clearer fame, as modest as she's fair,
And so ingenious.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: I would excuse
Her modesty, but she may be converted
In time; though sturdy oak we know, and so forth

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Your father
It seems his willing ear hath catched the news
Of your arrive.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: See if he first knows me,
'Tis a wise father now knows his own child.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: My dearest Borgia, comfort of my age.
My joy of soul, a father's prayers and blessing
Make thee a happy man, my eyes must speak
Part of my joy in tears, welcome from Naples.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Your pardon sir
That thus I steal upon you, I would hope
My sister —

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: And will be a glad soul to embrace her brother

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Your pardon sir that I seemed strange to you.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: 'Tis recompense now that you please to own me.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Julio an honest gentleman, and one
That loves us Borgia.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: I hear my uncle
Has left us —

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: A good estate, there's the less cause
To mourn for him.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: We must all tread that path,
Here is a friend of mine to whose trust and favour
I have been much engaged.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Sir what I want
In language, I'll supply with other welcome,
Please you to honour my poor wife.

sp.speaker: Pis:
sp.l: The service
Of my unworthy life is yours, command it,
I would you had another handsome daughter.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I presume you were presented a glad object
To Lucio, your affections grew from children.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: To Lucio we carry but one heart.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Do not forget his name now.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: But my son
We dwell to long thus public, let us perfectEnter Pietro.
Our ceremony at home, Pietro
One of the favourites creatures.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: 'Tis the Duchess,
Command Mercutio you wait upon her
Presently at court, and bring young Borgia
Along we to expect her grace's pleasure.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: What makes your countenance change sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: My fears poor Borgia for thee.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: While my aged arms are in,
a loving contention to embrace thee,
I wish thee from hence this ground betrayed thee,
Embark again, the seas have used thee kindly,
Trust them again, or any land but this:
This will undo us both, the joy of seeing thee
Made me forget thy danger.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Danger sir,
What have I done, to call these fears upon you?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Take heed, be wise, I know not what to think on't

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: What hast done sayest, nothing to dishonour thee,
Thou killed'st him fairly.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Killed I think; you were best
Be Aurelio again, and leave your sister
But I'll fish out the circumstance, walk melancholy.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Although your son has pleased
To call me friend, I find he has reserved
Something he would not credit to my bosom;
I have observed his trouble, but unwilling
By moving questions to renew his sufferings:
If my particular knowledge of his fate
May be no prejudice, though it be without
My verge to serve him, I can willingly
Share in their grief that love him.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You speak nobly,
'Twas his misfortune sir provoked to kill
A gentleman, brother to Ursini, who
Was favourite to the Duke deceased, and now
Graced by the Duchess, by whose power he may
Command him dead, these summons I suspect;
But take my counsel Borgia, and deceive
His expectation of revenge, once more
He bids thee fly; would slay thee in his heart,
Let me run their displeasure.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Not for me sir,
I am resolved, 'tis better die at home,
Then waste my life an exile, I'll to court w'ye.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Thou art a fool, cannot I cast
Borgia's skin off when I please, I must
See my fair sister at a minute's warning,
Thou art evidence for me; father I wait you,
My sisters there you say, do not doubt me;
At worst, I'll have a trick to keep my head on:
Come friend and gentlemen.

div.stage: Enter Duchess, Ursini, Cornelia, Melinda, Laura ▪

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: You have prevailed Ursini: yet we thought
Of all men living you would least have been
A suitor for his pardon, but 'tis signed
He owes you for his life.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: Your mercy rather,
I have considered madam I did lose
A brother, whose repair I shall not find
Now in another's blood, the gentleman
Hath suffered, though not what the laws determine ▪
Many years penance, so severe, perhaps
That he is come by offering himself now
A sacrifice to your justice, to prevent
A death more killing, still to live a stranger
To his own friends and country.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: If your charity
Extend so far, the rest we have dispensed with,
He is returned for certain? he is either
Weary of life, or master of a confidence
That might have been his ruin.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: This will make
Your art of mercy shine the brighter madam.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: It will, but let me ask you good my lord,
Does this proceed out of a clear forgiveness:
Time I allow may qualify the thought
Of our revenge, and something else of pity
May so take off the roughness of our soul
That we may have a noble charity
To our enemy, but has your end no mixture
Of something else, that may advance a hope
to satisfy desire some other way?
No turn to profit or delight? be plain;
For I must know your breast.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: You shall see through me,
I dare not wear a thought less than transparent,
I love his sister madam, fair Cornelia
With those intents become me, in that flame
I sacrifice all thoughts that wound her brother
And wish no happier satisfaction,
And by that charm of her consent to love
My brother is redevivd in Borgia.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: You're brief, yet plain; how point Cornelia's
Affections.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: I have wooed her but in compliment,
And though there may be sons to admit
My services, I find she is all obedience
To her father, whom the apprehension
Of his son's fortune may have indisposed
To a present reconcilement.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: This one act
Will make him kind, and form him to your wishes.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: If they might have the happiness to be
Propounded by your highness to Mercutio,
I prophesy success, pardon great madam,
If after all your princely favours I
Beg this with many blushes, love is graced
By dwelling on your breath.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Ursini since
The Duke died you have found no loss in out
Esteem, to his ashes I have paid that duty
To grace whom he affected, and be confident
We shall not deny this, is he not come yet?

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: He will attend your grace — who wait.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Signior Mercutio
Expects your grace's pleasure, with him his son
Borgia

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Though we pardon him
we must put on a brow of some displeasure
And chide his fault, he may be encouraged else
To a second insolence.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Gently I beseech you,
There may be a punishment within your eye
To kill him, and so make the benefit
Is meant him, of no virtue, or to himself,
Or my design.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: How is the name of gentleman
Dishonoured by such desperate undertakings;
That more than guilty of humane blood, do kill
Even charity.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Is that he?
We sent for you Mercutio to tell you
How much you owe to good Ursini's love,
At whose earnest solicit we have signed
Young Borgias pardon, if you examine well;
You will have cause to place him in the first
Rank of your friends.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Shall I believe my eyes,
My understanding? how is Mercutio blessed?
Look boy the pardon, heaven reward thy charities;
My lord for saving one, command the lives
Of all our family, thou soul of honour;
Look Borgia.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: What d'ye mean
Kneel to the Duchess and acknowledge.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: I am lost here
Pisauro, an excellent creature.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: You'll spoil all,
She's yet your sister, I do like her too;
Kneel for your pardon, and you may choose your gallows
In time, wood I were hanged on no worse piece
Of timber, how nimbly would I climb the ladder,
ha you no sense? humble your knees to thank
Her highness and that gentleman.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Why does
That fellow kneel Ursini.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: 'Tis signior Borgia,
His heart is full of thanks.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I look not for 'em,
What do I feel? command him rise.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Dear madam.
Look calm upon him.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: As sure as you are my sister; do you doubt me?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: How now Cornelia, pray excuse me brother,
My joy to see you safe doth half transport me.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: I am converted now,
And do believe there are some handsome women;
Young gentleman, not too much, too much at once,
Remember you're her brother, he is taken.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Your grace is pleased to enlarge my happiness;
My daughter is much honoured, but I must
Beseech your lordship to allow we may
In such a cause as this, inquire her judgement,
And since by'th bounty of your highness, I
Have a son now, whose joy may be concerned in't;
I would not willingly conclude her marriage
Without his voice too.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: I am confident
To incline his favour, since she has declared
Herself no enemy.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: Sir I have a suit to you.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: You have deserved
My life, which ought to waste itself in service.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: I am an honourer of your fair sister,
It rests in you to perfect my ambition.
And make her mine.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: How do you mean my lord.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Now he's put to't, she is Ursini's mistress.
As he is Borgia, he can have no
Pretence to oppose him, if he discover
And be Aurelio again, he destroys all
Hope for himself, for I perceive he's taken with her,
I know by the motion of his nose, which pants
Like the bellows of an organ.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Sir your father's
Voice speaks in yours, you now command my destiny
If you will make me happy.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Noble sir,
I am sorry where such infinite merits plead
I have no power to serve your noble wishes,
And keep the honour of a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Your family I take it can receive
No stain by my alliance.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Mistake not I beseech you,
I have already engaged myself to a gentleman
Of a noble house in Milan, one Aurelio
Andreozzi.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Who on the fight of
Her picture which I gave him, courted me
To woo the substance for him, promising
To follow me in person, being one
To whom I had many obligations
In the Milan court, I pawned the credit
Of a gentleman, to assist his fair desires,
If in few days he come to Urbin; but
I am confident his young affections
Which had no other life but what a dead
Representation could infuse, will soon
Vanish again, and leave ▪ me to be serviceable
In what you will command me, and be sure
I will not rack your patience to much length;
if in few days he appear not, I will think
My promise disobliged, and direct all
My abilities to make your wishes prosper:
It will become my gratitude.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: The pleasures of the court will so abate
His thoughts this way, that I presume your lordship
Will soon be master of that amorous province
You aim at, and much honour your poor servant.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: Let this confirm, I am yours.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: So so, this was indifferently well carried, I was jealous
Of a more lame come off.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Add this one
To your other princely favours madam, and
Admit this gentleman to kiss your hand.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Without much suit my heart would have conveyed
That to my lip, a very handsome gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: What said the Duchess? do not her eyes fix
Upon my brother? how now Cornelia,
I am his sister; yet I had
No acquaintance with this turbulent passions
When I last saw him.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: What does her highness mean,
She speaks to Ursini, but her eye directs
Some language this way, Borgia dost observe?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: And wonder, but I see nothing in her eyes
To be afraid of.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: If the Duchess should be in love with him
Here were a purchase, I do verily
Believe here will be an end of all our wars,
If he have but the grace to march upon
This service and charge home: smiles, smiles upon him;
Well Aurelio Andreozzi, 'tis very possible
You may meet with your match if he mount her,
I'll bring a ladder to his sister's fort
And then the town's our own, she calls him to her.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Her grace is very pleasant, good good heart
been patient.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: She plays with him, good, better,
Ay, is your spirit up my nimble Duchess?
Would I had the conjuring of it down ▪ Ursini
Looks like a whelp had lost his tail already.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: I was jealous she would chide and frown upon him, prayed her be gentle, and look calm, is't come to this?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Ursini, I have thought how to supply
That place of secretary that is vacant, see
That Borgia be sworn, we apprehend
His fitness.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I hope this will please you
Ursini, we can grace whom you present ▪
He is more gentleman than to forget
How for your sake we honour him; I shall
Betray too much of women, Borgia
Attend us; come Cornelia, Ursini,
Mercutio, make the court not so much stranger.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: I'll follow: what dost think of this Pisauro.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: I think the Duchess loves thee, and make use on't,
Lose no applications, that't her secretary ▪
A degree to more inward endearments,
If she do love thee, and —

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: She knows best
What appetite she has, let men counsel thee,
Be not modest, we are made.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Thy father a count, thou a Duke, Ursini
A coxcomb, I a fine gentleman, and one
That would be glad of the worst of your
New female acquaintances.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Be not you a tyrant, I'll do penance
In a white sheet with thy sister for't.

div.head: Actus secundus.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: No signior Aurelio come yet? No master to be heard on, he is a fine gentleman to use his squire of this fashion; where should he be, he commanded me not to be drunk, he is drunk; and drunk and dead drunk, he would have had the grace to reel home to his lodging before this time of night else: let me see, what if the flesh have led him a to side? He is fallen into some brake, some wench has tied him by the legs, and nothing else can excuse him to me; yet now I think on't, he does forget Pimponio, he was not wont to be his own purveyor, my art for the choice of his pullen, has been allowed if he do get and so forth an excuse for physic, and come home foundered, the disease was none of my choosing, it came not through my office; stay, what if my signior be dead? umph? dead? my heart misgives, they may be killed, my master has the spirit of fighting in him, and his companion is the devil at it, an aglet hole or two in their hearts, and in a strange place, my signiors, are never missed, 'tis so, if he be dead — bring forth the portmanteau.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Bring forth my portmanteau my diminutive knave, and tell thy father I would speak with him, he is dead, he would not have trusted me so long with his money else, now will I make myself his heir, defy the world and Aurelio's ghost; but first of all I must outface mine host, so let me examine; very good linings, bag and baggage, you are mine own,

sp.speaker: As.
sp.p: He is coming sir, 'tis very late.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Never too late to tell money, fetch me a brace of gennets I will mount 'em, a covey of courtesans; stay Pimponio, be not mad before thy time, who shall I say I am? A prince at least, I have it;

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: What would this fellow have, no news of your master?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Speak that word no more on thy allegiance, here go to bed and rise with a clean shirt.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: This is gold, what does the fellow mean?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: No fellows neither, 'tis time to show myself, where is thy boy?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Kneel down and ask me blessing.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.p: This does look a blessing, shall I ask another?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Ask any thing but what I am.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Stay there, 'tis dangerous to pronounce me yet, I will be still disguised, my men are absent.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Thou art wise, thine ear, I am a prince.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: The reason of my shape thou shalt know hereafter, thus Jove has been disguised.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: It was my pleasure they should call me so, I have not found 'em trusty;
How fares the Duchess?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: This boy shall wait on me, I'll have ye all.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: What country shall I choose? to be a prince of Italy is too well known, Spain stands convenient, and far enough, where I have been too, I'll have you all to Spain.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: For your preferments, when thou hast got a chapman for this tub thou livest in, let me know't.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.p: A prince of oranges, he a Spanish prince?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: They wonot travel thither to disprove me, to tell the truth, I suspect my two grooms have betrayed me; I come hither to be a suitor to your Duchess.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: You do not know my plot, these gentlemen my servants should cunningly have preferred me to be the Duchess fool.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: But for a time, there's mystery in that
By this means I resolved to try her nature
And disposition ere I married her,
For I can have at this present four Kings daughters, the eldest of 'em is but seven years old, which shows the parents dote upon me, and would make sure of me betimes.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Grace, umph, thou must be advanced, let me see, what office, o, thou shalt have a place at my return in the galleys, dost hear, a yerking preferment.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Thou shalt be — a picaro, in your language a page, my chief picaro; by degrees you may send for all your generation, I will see them mounted.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: A pox pimp you, they are alive again, now am I a dead man.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: There is a certain movable eccliped a portmanteau.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Would your tongue had been clipped.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Wherein there are some golden friends of ours.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Let me see their complexions, where are they? look for the signior your master a month hence?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Does he not carry it handsomely, he knows not I have discovered myself to you.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.p: With your pardon sir, is not this signior a prince disguised ▪

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: A prince of puppets, who Pimponio?

sp.speaker: As.
sp.l: And you one of his servants, to whom with
Your other fellow called signior Aurelio,
His person stands discovered, he came hither
To court our Duchess, he has promised us
At his return to Spain to make us grandees.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Has he betrayed himself, nay then my duty
if please your excellence.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: A prince cannot be hid though under mountains,
But my dear prince, the bags must go with me
While you keep state ith' inn.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: If I did think thou wouldst carry it handsomely ▪
Well, I'll excuse thee to thy master, here
When thou hast domineered away this bag
Thou mayst hear more; keep thine own counsel, and
Thy master sha'not own thee, if thou hast
Any fagary, drink, and indulge thy genius;
I'll see thee again before thy reign be out,
No words but be a prince, and scorn to know us
And so I take leave of your excellence.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: I sha'not know myself, am not I a prince
Indeed, that have been long concealed? this is a bag
And full of golden friends, umph, however I will
Spend it like an emperor, these are not robes
Fit for a prince I take it, Grutti, boy
I entertain you both my groom and page, and
Say unto you, snakes go cast your coats ▪
Here's earnest for new skins, when things are ripe
We will to court.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: What thinks your grace of going to bed

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: I am too sober, let the whole house be drunk first ▪ 'twill please us well to see the servants gambol, we purpose
To be drunk ourselves in state too:
Let me have fifty strumpets.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Strumpets I say, they'll make the greater noise.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.p: Your grace will be a Hercules.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: I will, and thou shalt be captain of the pigmies under me, this room's too narrow, beat down the walls on both sides, advance your lights and call the country in, if there be a tailor amongst 'em he shall first take measure of my highness, for I must not longer walk in quirpo.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: A strange turn
From that could temper we imagined
In her highness.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I have heard of charms and philters.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: If travel have these glorious effects
I'll abroad too.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Is master of a noble soul.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Soul, nay let that alone, ladies do not look
After the soul so much, the body will serve their
Turn, so it be nimble, and at their devotion,
If you observe, he is graced by all the ladies
As if he were their general minion,
I do not like his sister's eyes upon him,
They whirl too much and seemed to shoot an envy
Upon the Duchess favours.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I am confident
Thou hast no murmur in thy thoughts against him.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I but express my wonder,
In that I think the whole court had a share:
He knows I love him, 'twill become his fear
How to secure Ursini.

sp.speaker: Lu:
sp.l: He preferred him
First to her highness.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Not with expectation
To be supplanted, I make question
If the humour hold, whether she may not marry him,
That's a round higher than her favourite:
Had hope to climb.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Although I honour Borgia
And wish him heartily advanced, I would not
Kneel to him, my voice is for Ferrara
He is a prince, I would not for my state
This shod break off his treaty.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Thy ambassador
To his master, he is scarce minded.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Come she cannot,
fall so low, the passion is too violentEnter Ursini, and Ferrara.
To last — who are these?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: The ambassador and Ursini, what's the matter?
I fear some discontent.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: My lord let me
Prevail so far, I hope you imagine I
Am firm to you, I have more cause to be
Impatient, my whole strength at court's concerned,
But have more noble thoughts then to suspect
You can be slighted, think 'tis but a dream
In justice to your cause, and royal master
Put on no face of discontent, return
And see how things will close

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: 'Tis an affront
'Bove satisfaction, but the disgrace
Reflects beyond my person.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Had she studied
Honours to his ambition, it had
Not wronged her prudence, to have shown you more
Respect.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: But I was not considerable;
The young gentleman had taken up her eyes,
Her tongue, her feet, her understanding too,
I might have withered in my seat, no beam,
No discourse this way, but that once she was pleased
To ask me how I liked the gallants dancing,
I'll not disturb her revels.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Yet my lord
Have so much fortitude, 'twill be a means
If you return, to make her find her error
To your person, were she not my Princess
I should profess myself ashamed, out come
Let me beseech you to go back, leave not
The presence so, for your own honour sir
Observe a little more, I hope you sha'not
Repent my counsel.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I would ye would excuse me,
I shall but vex my eyes.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: You have power with me my lord.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: What will become oh this, what think you now?
They do resent it, and for ought I hear
Have little hope to mend it.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Can she be
In love so soon, well Borgia, if this
Hold, I'll applaud thy fate.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: For after this
Allowance, he'll be Duke of Urbin tomorrow,
Give thee joy bully, let me see if he
Turn prince, 'tis best for us turn beggars.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Court beggars, he'll deny us nothing,
Now for some witty knave to find out suits,
I must keep some in pension for that purpose,
They are profitable vermin,Enter Pisauro.
His companion.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Save you gentlemen, what d'ye mean?
Why stand ye bare?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: In being Borgias friend
It will become us.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: He knows no title yet,
But chief secretary to her highness, what honours
Are in her breast laid ▪ up for him, we know not
He has a mounting fate, and in his we
Pronounce you happy.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: We shall all be princes
In time ▪ but gentlemen let's be more familiar
We think so well of things, does he preserve
The Duchess smile, or does she use to make
At some time of the moon sport with her subjects.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: You are wide all the heaven sir, had you come
A little sooner you had heard discourse. Enter Borgia.
To clear your doubt, he's here himself.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Pisauro,
What will become on's, 'tis as thou sayest?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Why she is certainly in love, shalt in and see
How I am used, and yet I now come forth
To recover breath, I ha' danced myself to a jelly,
The ladies ha' no mercy; but the Duchess

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Is as I told thee mad, I prithee counsel me
Although her grace be pleased to show me favours
'Twere boldness to believe, and thank her.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: How?
I hope thou art not mad.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I know not whether
The fit will last, I may hold some proportion
With Cornelia, my supposed sister, she
Poor wretch does cast such speaking eyes upon me
As she were jealous of the Duchess too,
And wrings me by the hand when I dance with her.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: The Duchess sir calls for you.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I attend;
What were I best to do?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Dost make a question
Lose not the fortune that's presented in
The Duchess love, thy stars ordained thee for her;
I'll make a shift with Cornelia, look high
And prosper, when thou'rt a Duke, I say no more

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: What shall's do with Pimponio? that fool
May betray all.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: He is a prince before you
I ha' made him sure, and swollen him into a pride,
He shall not know you, but of that hereafter,
Away and please the Duchess.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: 'Tis late, good night my lord ambassador.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: 'Tis well I am bid good-night, yet all my hopes
Vanish in mists, what think you now cousin?

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: I know not what to think, let me wait on you
To your lodgings.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Tomorrow morning if I may be honoured
With your presence, I will impart a secret to you,
And be happy in your counsel.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: I obey
Any commands.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: For this time give me pardon, goodnight my lord.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: A happy night to your lordship,
After so many years spent in the court,
I am to learn the trick on't, these are actions
'Gainst my first rules, I am ignorant ▪
Of this new court philosophy, what should
The Duchess mean, so prodigal of her graces
To one she scarce remembers, with such open
Neglect to th' Duke's 'Ambassador? I was careful
She would not use him kindly enough, wert not
Affection to his sister, lies up my
Revenge, I'd drop it on his heart, but I
Must work with art, and by a counter magic
Dissolve his spell, or form him to my purpose. Enter Laura and Melanda.
You have been waiting on the Duchess ladies?

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: With what circumstance?
Is she still pleasant?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Strangely altered
Since young Borgia took his leave and melancholy:
Well, I suspect —

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: She'll scarce sleep
Tonight , for dreaming oth' gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Yes, we saw his departure my lord,
He kissed us both, but we put forward sirst,
He is the handsom'st gentleman; d'ye think
He wears his own hair?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I was about
To ask him once, but thought he was modest
And would ha' blushed, I would I had his picture.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: His substance madam, but take heed, the Duchess
Must have no rival, how d'ye affect his talk?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: That was not my part to observe, we did divide
Our provinces, each lady took a member
To examine, when we have conferred our notes
I'll tell ye what the body of ladies think on him.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Nay we'll take him a pieces ere we ha' done.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: And who shall set him together again? my ladies
I wait on you.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Your lordship will too much honour us.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: 'Tis the way to my own lodging.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: If it were not the way my lord, your lordship
Could not be destitute of a lodging at court.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: Your charity would relieve me, use my service.

div.stage: Enter Ferrara and Pietro with a light.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: There is no such affliction to the soul
As that which should preserve it, love, a passion
That with consent betrays our understanding,
And leaves man but a heap of flame and ruins;
I was safe till I had seen her, busy fame
Took but possession of my ear, my own
Rashness and vanity engaged my person
To see what was commended, and I suffer for't,
Leave me.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Thou liest, 'tis light
And by these fires I see too much, away,
I shall soon reach my lodgings, night and I
Shall agree well together, if my stay
Be long, remember that you left me under
The palace windows, leave to be officious
And obey me — till this night she gave me fairExit.
Respect, and seemed to allow the loving treaty,
I was dull not to uncloud me all this while
The knowledge of my person had engaged her
beside my act of love, and so much confidence
Passed all retreat, and yet she is a woman,
Whose nature is unsteady as the waves,
Upon which foolish man runs desperate
To me a ruin.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Fortune thou smil'st too much, I shall suspect
Thy giddiness, take eyes to thee and see
To what a flattering height thou hast exalted
A credulous man.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What voice is that, it had
A sound of melancholy, darkness secure me.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: But why make I ridiculous application
To fortune? love is only active here;
The tyrant love, more blind than chance, I am
Full of distraction, there's a labyrinth
Within, and more I tread, the more I am lost
Betwixt the Duchess and Cornelia
My soul divides, I must not be a fool,
And for the fable of amorous love
Leave state that courts me with a glorious title,
And yet Cornelia is fury, and looks
Withal the charms of love upon her brow,
What will she do when she believes I am
No brother?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: 'Tis the new ague Borgia
That shakes the court, how confidently he talks
To himself, a light strikes from the Duchess window
And music; I'll observe, the gallant may
Have some appointment.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Alas poor lovesick lady, what if I
Attempted farther, the excuse will fall
More easy on a stranger, lady, hist.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: One that does wish the happiness
To see your face, you have blessed my ears already.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: My name's Borgia, if you be
A fair one of the court, time is not old
since I was a guest there.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: 'Tis he, I'll not lose
This opportunity, sir your boldness
Speaks you a stranger, and in part excuses
You are alone.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I expect not
Upon so small acquaintance you should know
My voice again, I am the Duchess sir.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Your grace's humble creature, may I hope
You'll pardon this attempt.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Upon condition
You will forget the freedom of our nature
And not grow insolent upon our favours,
We were late pleased to show you, 'twas not love
But mirth, we meant our court the wantonness
Of revelling nights, which we upon retirements
Know how to check and punish too in men,
That dare licentiously apply to our
Dishonour: if your service in that place
Of secretary we have named you for
Be diligent and faithful, we repent not
That choice, but on your life feed no ambition
Higher, it will be a degree next treason
To us, and the honour of Ferrara's Duke,
With whom because you are our secretary
We let you know our thoughts are fixed to marry,

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What blessing hath my ear took in? she is
Resolved to my desires.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Are you gone sit?
Sleep wisely if you can, we shall expect
Your attendance in the morning, but no thought
On forfeit of your life beyond what's duty.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I have enough tomorrow I resolve
To be myself, and with a state becoming
Ferrara's Duke, challenge this happiness,
Forgive dear Princess I suspected thee.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I heard your voice more loud than usual,
Whom spoke you to?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Here's nobody and please your grace.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: You hold some dialogue at the window then,
I'll know.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I must confess you are my Princess madam,
To whose least command I owe my blood and fortune.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.p: He speaks to me, how does he know I am here?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: And do not think I can be lost so much
In duty to interpret there was any thing
In me, that could deserve more than your pastime;
And let me fall and die beneath your anger,
When I transgress so far, as to forget
My humble fate which only can be blessed
With my obedience to you, I had not
One saucy application of your favours,
My heart shall bleed to death ere it shall find
One thought of so much impudence.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: How's this?
Since Cornelia has usurped my name
And frighted him, what should make her officious
He is her brother, I must hear no more
Of this — you are mistaken all this while,
I am Cornelia your sister.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.p: You well distinguish voices, yet she's gone.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: My joy of soul, dearest Cornelia.
'Tis she that I must trust to.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Is't e'en so?
Dear brother, leaving all your studied compliments
I do not like your dilatory reasons
To Ursini, I may hear you as a brother,
But must not trouble you to choose my husband;
It is the Duchess pleasure, I should marry
Ursini, an advancement more than I
Can hope, from your election of a stranger
and set your heart at rest, howe'er I seemed
Inclining, destiny is not more fixed,
Than the affection I owe Ursini,
Him I resolve to marry, and before
The next day's light is wasted.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I am undone
A 'Both sides, hear me yet but speak.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Not Borgia, the whole town's mistaken
My name is Aurelio Andreozzi,
I was born in Milan, with my friend designed
To see some service in the German wars;
At the first sight I must confess I loved thee:
To enjoy thy conversation more freely,
I was content to seem what men would call me

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I can give thee proof,
But to no purpose now, and tell thee too
Enough to make thee think I may be worthy,
But since 'tis so, I am glad you ha' discovered
Your resolution so soon, good night te'e,
I'll make no noise tomorrow, when I take
My journey.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Stay, he must not be foe lost,
This is a strange discovery, if you can
Bring testimony that you are not Borgia,
You shall not sir repent your coming hither,
Nor yet despair of any noble ways
That may reward your good opinion,
'Tis late; a lover's dream charm all your senses,
And waking find your wishes, if you please
Until I ask a further satisfaction,
Be still concealed.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: There may be hope, although
My first love I confess reflect on this,
The Duchess yet, had not been much amiss,

div.head: Actus tertius.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Why, I shall hardly take thee for my own natural child.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.p: Let me alone with my son, if I do not fit him, let me never find the way into my own breeches again, I would be loath to die in a wrong case and be mistaken in another world; is the music ready, and the wine father? can the fellows do their dance handsomely, in stead of a mask to entertain his highness, I am sorry my legs are out of tune, I have a great mind to be capering.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: My own wit, my own natural wit to a hair.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.p: Not too much hair of your own, and wit together, father, 'tis not the fashion: d'ye hear, whatsoever I say, be you drunk time enough to justify it, the bills shall be discharged without scrupulous examination, souse in wine and give him sea room, if his head leak we will pump his breeches, he shall not sink with all his ballast I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: A witty crack, and my own boy still.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.p: Your own boy? take heed what you say, lest you be driven to justify it, you have no mind to wake my mother from her grave, 'tis enough I ask you blessing, I do long to be metamorphosed, and pursue his princely humour out of breath — music, 'tis well, his grace is upon entrance.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.p: I know my cue to enter.

div.stage: Enter Pimponio, like a Spanish don, and servants.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: And how, and how do things become? We were in clouds but now.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Out of the clouds and please you.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: There is no infidel among you then,
You all believe I am a prince, d'ye hear,
At all adventures let it go no further,
There are no traitors I hope amongst ye ▪

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Traitors, we will cut off any man's neck that dares but think so.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Do and I will justify it, hang necks among friends, although I am pleased to reveal the majesty of my person to you, it is not fit every one should know so much, you are strangers , and therefore I dare trust you, but the Duchess must not hear on't upon your lives; she and I must be better acquainted when I see my time; I'll tell you, 〈◊〉 ●oy may take me i'th head to look like a fool again, it may, greatness is given to humours, and giddiness will run in a blood, if it do, do not know me.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: For any other than I seem.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Thou art an ass, a prince may play the fool within his own dominions, or any other; provided they be of his own allies and confederates: I know where I am, but we are not merr●y reach me a chair and a bottle of wine, every one take his charge.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Will not your highness have the dance first?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: They will dance the better when they are three quarters drunk.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.p: We do not observe men of your nation to be so jovial.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Not subjects I grant you that, but weSound a health.have privilege music, and give fire at once — so, but methinks it were necessary there were some difference in our drinkings; all are not princes, reach me a bigger bottle,Sound a health.I will preserve my state, this is a princely draught —We drink alone.so — why have we not a concubine?

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.p: Brave prince, with what a majesty he drinks.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Now let 'em frisk the dance you have prepared, I am ready to accept it.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.l: And it shall please your grace,The dance which ended.
There is a high German desires to speak with you.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.p: The high german that was at court, he's a man of mighty parts and known to all the princes in Christendom, what comes he for?

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: I fear you are betrayed sir, and that the Duchess has sent for you.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: For me, I wonot come yet.

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.p: Do not affront him sir, for your own sake, this high german has beaten all the fencers in Europe.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Let him beat all the world, what's that to me? shall he make a prize of me?

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: But if he come ambassador from the Duchess.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: That's another matter, give me the tother bottle —
Now let all the cantons of Swiss come. Enter Ascanio in swizzers habit.
Which is the high german? let me see him.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: He's one of the lowest high Germans that e'er I looked upon.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: And we embrace this lowness: d'ye hear sir, are you a high german?

sp.speaker: As.
sp.p: I was so at the beginning of the wars, what we are beaten to you may discern.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Are you beaten to that? you'll be a very little nation and the wars continue.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.l: I have a message to deliver you,
The fair Duchess of Urbin, whom I wait on,
Hearing a person of your blood and quality
So meanly lodged, by me desires you would
Accept an entertainment in her court.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: We give the Duchess thanks, how knew she I was here?

sp.speaker: As.
sp.l: It was impossible
You should stay undiscovered many hours.
Princes have strange intelligence, and you may
As soon tie up the sun beams in a net
As keep yourself unknown; for my own part
I am honoured in the embassy, and shall
Be proud to write myself your pensioner
As I am to all the royal blood in Christendom.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: O pensioner, 'tis the least honour we intend thee, I am a natural prince as sure as I live; here wear this gold, there's more to drink our health, we are pleased no man be sober at our return, as he will answer it, you may be all my subjects ▪ if I marry the Duchess I'll hang you all.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: In chains of preferment, drink I say, and drink to purpose, what will become of me now? stay, a word with you high German, what will the Duchess do with me do you think?

sp.speaker: As.
sp.l: 'Twere sin to say she'll honour you, for you
Are above all addition but her love;
Your wit, your blood, your person, do not lose
The opportunity, yet I prophesy
You will be affronted.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: No matter, I ha' been affronted a hundred times, but by whom?

sp.speaker: As.
sp.l: Questionless by some great ones,
And perhaps beaten.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: I have been beaten too upon good occasion,
And will again to save my honour; beaten?
I can take the strappado, beside in this part
I am insensible, a kick is cast away.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.l: If you be valiant and endure, it will
Engage her love the more, but I know
Your breeding will afford you impudence
To overcome their envies, and secure
This dukedom to yourself, go on boldly,
My counsel shall attend.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: I will go on, and fear no beating, well
I cannot knight thee, yet prove but a witch
I'll make thee one of my privy counsellors.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: No more, my duty will not let me hear it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: You are his friends, I should not else be pleased.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: We have said nothing to afflict you thus,
We did expect this would ha' made you merry.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: A son's preferment was not wont to be
Such discord to a father, a loving father,
For so we took your constitution.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: You were best tell me too he may be Duke.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: He is i'th road, I know not how he'll miss it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: This is three quarters treason, though I love
My son, I must not cherish this ambition.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: But it will be more than three quarter's treason
If you presume to check the Duchess pleasure,
And murmur thus if she resolve to marry,
And make your son a Duke, you'll not turn rebel.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Defend allegiance, gentlemen mistake not
Although I love my son, I'll not be guilty
Of any thought to cross her, but I should
Be sorry he should cast away himself.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: As men do use when they
Do hang or drown themselves.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Have you sense
And talk thus wildly.
The riddles you have told me.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Do you count
Your son lost by the Duchess loving him?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Go find your wits again, and use 'em better,
Can you be so ridiculous to think,
So wise, so modest, so religious
A lady can forget her state and honour
To place affection on my son.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: There have been
Presidents to make it seem no wonder.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: She had better ta'ne his head off, there had ended
My cares, the boy t'run mad, and what can follow
Think ye? go to, I'll to her highness presently.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: To pray her leave him to a natural death,
And choose some other to undo with pride
Of her large favours; gentlemen examine
But yourselves, could either of you two promise
To keep your wits, if such a grace were offered
To you? would it not tempt you to be mad,
To think of being a Duke? speak honestly,
is't fit indeed you should be less than mad?
There be some men ith' world ha' lost their senses
When they but chewed the cud of a bare lordship,
I ha' known a knighthood has turned some men's wits,
The very noise o'th spurs; then do not blame me
If I desire my son sober and sensible,
And now I think on't I'll first seek him out.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I think the old man's mad indeed,
Dear madam Laura,

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Then I can walk and wait on you.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: You have the same haste too,
Thou art a piece of the Duchess cabinet,
I must hear some news.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I know a trick to make thee fruitful yet,
Nay I can mend my pace lady an you put me to't.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Good sir the reason why you wonder at me
Above all other women, what in me
Appears so full of prodigy.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: I'll tell you,
You're young and handsome.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Should I grant I were,
This were no miracle.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Withal this youth and handsomeness you're a maid
And live at court too, this I hope's not ordinary.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: What wonder will your fancy create next.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: You're sound too, or your phisnomy deceives me.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: The privilege of my brother's friend must not
Engage me to a mockery.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: I was
About to say you're patient too, I see
Something would make you angry, but return
To your first temper, and I'll soon acquaint you
With all my purpose lady, to all these
Commendations, which meet not in all women,
you have birth and fortune, and the favour of
The Duchess.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: All these carry no such wonder
If I have understanding.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: No, no, you
Are all the wonder madam that with these
Advantages a your side to draw up men's
Affections, yet as you despair to have
A husband to the discredit of your sex,
Who article at twelve to be dissemblers;
You are in love.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: In love, is that a sin?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Nay, nay, you court a gentleman with eyes
That are not lawful.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Is it your mirth or madness.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: No, no, you are mad, worse, I'll prove it,
You dote upon your brother, come 'tis impious,
Purge, purge betime, your blood is foul, I'm plain
There's some on't in your face now that would blush
I see through your hearts, a little more
Had spoilt him quite, he had forgotten all laws
Of nature and religion, and been fond
To both your shames; a brother, and a sister
Tempt one another, good heaven where is conscience
And modesty become? preserve yourself
You have yet a good name, keep it and drink julips,
You'll find the benefit in your veins.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: You have
Been very bold upon my constitution.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: I know it better than your doctor, come
Do not deny it, I make no proclamation;
What is't to me more than my Christian care
You should not hurt your souls, he is my friend
Betray him not, 'tis no good sister's part
I can assure you, if you be not dull
Or blind with giddy passion, you may see
another star shoot influence on him;
Be wise and envy not the Duchess favours,
Your vessel may be rigged, and trimmed, and launched
Into a calmer sea, and return fraught
With lawful prize hereafter, I ha' stirred her,
But must not be too hasty.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I shall show
Myself too full of guilt.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: You are troubled at it,
A sign of grace; howe'er you think of me
Now in the heat of counsel I'm your friend,
You'll find it so, I kiss your hand, farewell.
D'ye hear? but two words more, if you do find
As being acquainted best with your own body,
No disposition to hold out longer,
I ha' that will cure you, and I'll justify't
Before the college — take me,
D'ye mark, that does it, I kiss your hand,
Again farewell, and have a conscience,
I'll tell you more next time, this way may work.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: This gentleman's discourse though somewhat wild
And without method shakes me, I am lost
If I obey, I know not what within me
Too prompts me to a love so irreligious;
He is my brother, holy thoughts possess me,
And when a furious passion seeks to invade
My will, destroy it heaven — he's here I dareEnter Duchess and Borgia.
Not stay to tempt my frailty, let them move
With joy, I am not in my sphere of love.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: But tell me signior, nay we are pleased
You should be free, upon what confidence
Knowing your guilt, and danger to reward it
Durst you return to Urbin.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I was more fortunate
Than I have reason for, and yet my country
And friends were precious madam, nor could life
In such a wilderness abroad, where none
durst own me, be a benefit; there was
A blessing in my fate to meet your mercy
That gave me boldness.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Cunningly dissembled,
You met no lady then in all your travel,
I mean none whom you called mistress, with
Her loving magic to lay charms upon you
And forced your stay.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: None madam, I was not
Worth any lady's thought, none were so lost
To their own judgements to imagine me
More than a walking shadow, or if any
Had cherished better thought of me a stranger,
They quickly found, they had not placed it right,
On so much barrenness which left their charity
To pay itself.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: You do not promise such
A hard and horrid composition,
But love may find a shift to enter more
Than skin deep in your bosom, but perhaps
You left your heart at home, and could not then
Dispense with new engagements, it was so,
And for her sake you willingly forgotten
Your danger to return, nay be not troubled,
Confession will not injure you, I like
You should prefer the beauties of your country.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: It cannot be thought flattery, if I
Acknowledge with the narrowest observation
My eyes could take, no place hath been more fruitful
In beauty than your own, and it doth hold
Proportion with your excellence, all should
Be fair and imitate your first example.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I see you can be when you lift a courtier,
But this confirms your love is planted here;
And since we are fallen by accident upon
This subject, we'll pursui't a little further;
Come I must know your mistress, do not doubt
I shall disturb the progress of your loves.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: What answer shall I frame, things are not ripe
yet for discovery, so please your highness
You would be modest, and excuse, be wiser
And apprehend my meaning to advance
Your wishes, 'tis within my power to effect
As much as your ambition can aim at:
Who is it if her heart be stubborn, we
Can make it soft; if great above your fortune,
We can raise you to her equality,
Or bring her down to your level, since we ha' promised
In hope not to repent: either declare
The mistress of your thoughts, and find them prosper,
We are not used to express such bounteous language,
But be the proudest, greatest in our duchy ▪
Without all limitation, she shall carry
No birth or state here, to despise the service
You fairly mean her ▪ if we fail in this,
We will not think our strength worth the preserving

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: The Duke of Ferrara with a glorious train
Is come to court, and as the loud voice is
Given out by himself, to claim you for his wife,
For which he has your promise.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: How our promise?
Can princes be so insolent, beshrew
His haste, but we shall lose much of our honour
To give no ceremony to his person?
Howe'er our thoughts point, we will entertain him
And dress our face in smiles.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: His looks renew
My sufferings, I have not power to manage
My wild affection, my heart will not
Be denied but by a secret destiny.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Ha, Cornelia
I hope you are not courting Borgia,
He is your brother, know your place within
our train.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: She's jealous, jealous, stars I thank you,
'Tis clear as light she does affect me now:
Did she not put me to't, to name my mistress,
Yet in a shadow pointed at herself?
Be she the proudest, greatest in our duchy
Without all limitation, I marked that
And had my sense — if great above your fortune
We can raise you to her equality:
Fine morals, poor Cornelia loves me too,
But I must give her no encouragement:
Her grace is much the better woman — ha,Loud music.
sp.stage: A passage over the stage, Duke, Duchess, Ursini, Julio, Lucio, Pietro, ladies.
sp.l: She appeared discontent when first Cornelia
Brought her the news, yet they march lovingly
Together, but that ceremony must
Be allowed at court, where shift of face and tongue
Are wisely to be practised — my good lord.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Your servant Borgia.
'Tis her grace's pleasure every gentleman
That has relation to the Duke, taste all
The bounties of her court.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: None dare
To affront a groom on forfeit of his place,
Let all the offices of entertainment
Be free and open.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: I shall signify
These her commands.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: And they that of her own
Court are ambitious to express their duties
Let it appear in keeping this day solemn
To wine and mirth, that every brow may speak
A joy and welcome to the Duke.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Here's like to be a triumph, with your lordship's
Pardon; was that the Duke of Ferrara

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Yes of Urbin shortly, when their marriage
Is perfect, every subject's heart prays for it,
And sent their acclamations to heaven
To see her highness lovingly salute him,
He's a brave prince.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: A good round gentleman,
He did not fly hither; I heard talk of an
Ambassador.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: A cloud for his own person
Till his affairs came to maturity.
He stood concealed toth' Duchess, but last night
He gained her princely word to marry him,
And is this morning bright in his own glories.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: I'll build more faith upon his honour
Fast as a contract.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: To what painted paradise
Would she ha' led me? wood I had my sister now.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: With this joy
I had forgotten my own, Borgia; brother
Let not the sound be unwelcome, 'tis the Duchess's
Pleasure to honour her unworthy creature
Ursini, by appointment of our marriage
To wait on hers.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: With your sister,
I'll not suspect your love, since fair Cornelia
Is not displeased to be directed by
Her highness, and be confident my love
Shall make the memory of it welcome to you;
You will excuse me if I take my leave,
These hours are full of business, and I have
Many commands upon me.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: In good time,
I am in a good state again, I was an ass
To think the Duchess meant me any thing
But mockery, she told me so before
To make more sport, I ha' lost my sister too,
She's for Ursini's carving, I could curse
myself to Milan, but 'tis not impossible
I may retrieve Cornelia, by giving her
A timely satisfaction, I am not
Her brother Borgia:
There's all the hope is left, I shall be loath
To hunt two hares, and after lose them both.

div.head: Actus quartus.
div.stage: Enter Mercutio and Borgia at several doors.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: No great pleasure, I am almost hoarse with
Enquiring for you, I must ask you a question,
First let me examine your countenance.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I have no skill in metaposcopy,
D'ye know me?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I am not discovered sure,
What crotchet's this?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: He's proud, he wonot know me:
'Tis so, he's lost, he is undone, nay, nay,
It will become me to stand bare to you sir,
And teach my hams the officious cringe; be covered.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I know not how to interpret sir your language;
Yet I would hope you mock me not, although
It was the Duchess pleasure to create
Mirth from this barren heap, and counterfeit
Favours to try my duty, join not you
With others to enlarge my scorn, I am not
So tame of soul, but I have sense of all
Their jeers.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Their jeers? whom do you point upon?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I dare not name the Duchess; I am all
Obedience to her person, yet she might
Have placed her giddy humour somewhere else
It swells not me with expectation,
I was not made for state.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Do not you then
Think to be Duke.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Should any but yourself
Name such a title to me, I should answer
His question with a frown, and something else
To wait upon't, though I engaged my life
To a fresh danger, but I am instructed
By nature and religion to be calm
At what you say.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: On this condition
I'll give thee leave to beat me, 'twas my fear
Thou hadst an easy faith, and wert transported
Indeed out of thy wits, but since I see
Thou art not mad, I will commend a wife to thee

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: To me, I thank you sir, not yet,
I shall be mad indeed then, I will marry
None but my sister, take my word.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I cannot rail upon the Duchess safely;
A wife, my mother's dead.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I think you would not have her out of heaven.
'Twere little charity, and the whole sex
Were in a dead sleep were't not fin to wake 'em;
A wife, I'll seek my sister.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Stay and take
My keys ▪ this opens to my gold, go home
And take out ten bags.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: To spend 'em, all's thine own, leave something for
Cornelia, because perhaps she'll marry,
And I am satisfied, a prudent boy,
How am I bound to heaven that he's not proud,
Nor taken in the subtle toils of women?
He'll never marry, how shall I consume
My estate? Dost hear, a little portion
Will serve Ursini with thy sister ▪

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Must
He marry her?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I let him, we shall please
The Duchess too, and when she is disposed
The rest is ours to revel with.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Did you not meet my son?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You are deceived, he's choleric, and let
Me advise you gentlemen, although I know
He loves you, do not mock him, he's no fool;
No bladder to be swollen with breath of praise
And lady's jigs, he is sensible he is,
And will not be the hateful stock of pastime
To grooms and pages.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: What do you mean my lord?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Call him not Duke, I counsel you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Nor d'ye not think it possible it may be

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Have patience, and we do not, we have altered
Our opinions, and are clear of your side now.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: As the wheels move we do think nothing less,
Your son shall not be Duke, there is no fear on't
Whilst Ferrara lives.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: He shall not, very peremptory,
You are no oracles, would I were Duchess
For half an hour, he should be Duke, d'ye hear now;
No matter who repented: I thought you
Had been his friend, he sha'not be a Duke?
Howe'er I thought on't, it becomes not you
To circumscribe his fortune, he can number
Descents of noble blood, and had his breeding;
Has none of the worst faces, heads, nor hearts,
Howe'er you value him and discharge your bolts
At random thus, he sha'not.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: He shall not be a Duke.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Did not I say he was mad?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: That was dissembled,
He has cause now to see a turn i'th stream,
And Ferrara only hopeful with the Duchess,Enter Pisauro and Ascanio.
What thing is that?

sp.speaker: As.
sp.l: He will lay about like a prince, d'ye think
we may present him safely? if you say
The word I'll wind him up to an emperor.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Keep thy shape boy, we wonot lose the sport,
And happily I will acquaint these gentlemen.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.l: If I
Should be whipped heartily for my conceit,
The little high german would not take it kindly,
It may be the court largesse; but no matter,
I have some gold and dare venture the last
At any time for coin of this complexion.

sp.speaker: In.
sp.l: 'Twill be excellent,
And please her highness, she has commanded
All liberty of mirth, I'll undertake
To prepare her.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: About it then, I'll have
My part i'th interlude, lose no time boy,
Thou shalt be prince of Pigmyland for this:
The Duchess, I'll withdraw.

div.stage: Enter Duchess, Ferrara, Ursini, Borgia, Cornelia ladies.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: My lord, you make me wonder, challenge me
Of promises? though I acknowledge it,
No act that could reflect with a dishonour
Upon our person, yet we must not be
So jested into marriage, you are a prince
Of an unquestioned merit, take not these
Imaginary ways to advance your hopes
In us, we are yet free as you my lord,
And shall not in a dream give up ourself,
Were we disposed to marry or contract
Ourself, the day shall witness it without
A blush, let guilty souls call night to cover
Their promises, we are innocent.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Good madam
Render me not so lost to my own senses,
To the honour of a prince basely to coin
A language for my purpose, though you may
Repent the last night's freedom, and correct
Your judgement of me, make me not so miserable
to let the court think I invented this
As destitute of nobler ways to move you,
But I presume this is to try my patience
And make my joys at last more precious
By this delay; I know you are all virtue
And cannot stain yourself by a denial
Of any syllable you speak.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: With pardon
Of your grace, I shall laugh if you persist thus:
You had a pleasant dream, but lovers
Are flattered in their sleep, I speak to you.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Then madam I take leave, to tell you 'tis not
Done like a Princess of that character
We have received, and if I had no witness
I see what mirth we are prepared for.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Witness
There is too much at stake my lord already,
To rack this argument for your own fame,
Proceed not to enlarge it, we would rather
Confess some guilt against ourself, then let
You honour be exposed to such straight censure
For loving us, yet if you would be silent
In this we shall be proud, in other things
To have denied you nothing, and be ashamed
You took our court so unprepared to honour you.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Was ever such a mockery, I see
I must produce more testimony, you see
Can justify if you please, I have affirmed
Nothing but truth, although my willing ear
Catched up the voice, she spoke it to you signior.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: That she resolved to marry us.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Your excellence
Must pardon me, I heard her highness speak
No language to that purpose.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: We honour
You Borgia for acquitting us.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: 'Tis truth her highness never spoke so, but I did
whom supposed the Duchess, and this must
Sound hope in him to be so negative.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: It seems you have concluded, madam, I
Must be the general mirth.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I find Cornelia's
Cunning in this and must apply some compliment
For our own honour, good my lord your privacy.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: How ere her grace be a little impudent
I had been mad to justify the Duke
In such a cause, she has no mind to marry him,
And perhaps talked to me last night to try
My strength of wit, women are subtle creatures,
No matter though Ursini court my sister,
My ambitions fair a tother side again.

div.stage: Enter Julio, and Lucio, and whisper with the Duchess.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.p: 'Tis strange the Duchess should so mistake.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Upon
My conscience she heard the words.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Will you my lord
Admit of so much mirth.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Remit 'em then, the rest I'll clear hereafter
To your satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: D'ye hear, what prince d'ye mean to call yourself?

sp.speaker: Pis
sp.l: No I'll advise you
You shall be an Italian prince in Spanish habit,
Now I think better on't, 'tis quaint, and will
Be grateful for the witty novelty:
Every common prince goes in his country's fashion
Such as you are not ordinary, be bold.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Peace I may do you a courtesy,
Keep your own counsel and be ignorant
Of this strange creature, say you are —
The Duke of — thus disguised for reasons
Known to yourself.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: And be not beaten out of't.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: I wonot, let the high german first present me in a speech,
Is that the Duchess? so, so.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: You wonot be a fool and lose yourself,
And heaven knows what scorn to take notice on him,
Remember who you are.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.l: Duchess of Urbin never was your court
Graced with the presence of so brave a prince
As this the darling and delight of Christendom.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.l: And cousin not yourselves he is no Spaniard.
But of Italian sprightly breed, a man
Famous in arts and arms, as shall appear
If any man dares question him, should your grace
But see him at some royal exercise
You would think him more than mortal, he shall pitch
The bar with any of your guard, or drink with 'em;
Wrestle with both the West and North Olympics,
Sings like the Arabian bird, and can outdance.
The nimble elephant, so rarely skilled
In music, that he has a great ambition
To go to hell to challenge Orpheus
To play with him on any instrument
From the organ to the jew's-trump.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.l: These are the outside of his qualities,
But look within him, and your grace shall find
Enough to ravish you.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.l: With all these virtues and advantages
Of blood and state he comes to court your highness.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: We are infinitely honoured, and would thank him,
But that we know not yet this prince's name.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.p: Duke of Ferrara madam is his title.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: That is the Duke of Ferrara, what d'ye mean?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Stand to't and say he is a counterfeit
A mere impostor, be not beaten out on't.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Are you Duke of Ferrara sirrah, ha.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: I am Duke of all the world, what's that to thee?
High german stand close to me.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.p: A true prince needs no buckler.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: 'Tis mine, thou art a counterfeit,
I hope your grace will know me another time.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: A base affront my lord, and suspect
A plot of Borgias to dishonour you ▪
He durst not stay to face it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I'll have's hear,
As for this wretch.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Do, do, I looked for this, a true prince can bear.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Madam you have not used me well.
I say no more.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Let him go madam, I'll call him to account hereafter.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.p: We are displeased, hence with that fool and whip him.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: You must be whipped and striped my scurvy don.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Whip a prince? what d'ye mean?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: You must be Duke of Ferrara.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: Duke of a fiddlestick, you do not mean, to let me
Catch an ague gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: The lash when the fit comes will keep you warm, do you know one Pimponio, he was a footman, you will be in case to overtake him presently, he has the heels on you, and you cannot give him so much weight, now you are light, stay but a little we'll send you a whip.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: How am I transformed, Duke of Ferrara quotha, would I were any thing, I know not what I am as they have handled me.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.p: I'll have the fool hanged then ▪

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.p: Alas poor fellow, ha, ha, ha, what art thou?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Nothing, I hope she does not know me again, I must deny myself.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Come hither sirrah,
Whose device was it to bid you say you were
Duke of Ferrara?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Alas not I madam, he is gone.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: The insolent fellow that made a fool of your highness.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: To obey your grace and be whipped.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: I'm very warm and please your grace.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: My clothes? I never wore any more in my life, I sweat with these.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: He has punishment enough, who waits?
Bid Borgia attend us.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: How now sirrah, what are you?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: A tumbler, do you know me?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Signior Borgia her grace calls for you.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: How signior Borgia? than I am not I, and there is no staying here to find myself, as I remember some friends of mine, did promise me a comfortable whip, I'll rather venture a cold then stay fort, I must be dukified, be persuaded into kicks — they'll return, I wonot tempt my destiny, she promised to hang me, and I can do that for myself when I have a mind to't.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.p: Kick that fellow out of the court.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: You are mistaken sir, he means somebody else, I have been kicked already.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.p: Let it re ward your pains.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Convey this to Mercutio, it creates him
Controller of our household, this I hope
Will merit more of his acquaintance with
Our court.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Leave us,Exit.
You may stay sir, what suit, what that you named?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Did not you say you had a suit to us,
I hope your modesty will teach you how
To limb it your request, that it may be
Such as may both become our grant and your
Acceptance, speak what is't

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: But in the confidence of your discretion
Name and enjoy what you desire.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: This bounty
Of language is beyond all my ambition.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Well sir to'th purpose, I would have you speak
To purpose now.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: To purpose, would I durst,
This exceeds all the rest, shall I be mad
And lose this opportunity.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Better? my happiness flows upon me
My suit is madam, you would be pleased to —
What shall I say, she looks so keen and tempting,
I have a great mind to kiss her.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Long since, my humble suit is to you madam, that —

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I may be numbered still among your creatures
And keep a blessing in your gracious smiles
Upon my humble service.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: A smile and humblest service, is this all?
You wonot purchase much by being a courtier.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: The greatest rise by favour, I ha' lost
An opportunity.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: She asks again, now I'll put her to't,
We are private, I have another suit madam.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.p: A courtier should have many, what is't made on?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: A pretty winter wearing, and keeps well
In fashion.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: May I presume to as ask your grace.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Audacious groom, how dares thy soul imagine
So great an impudence, almost treason to us,
Are all our favours thought so cheap? and we
Considered in the crowd of other women
Fit for your mixture, to be stained with loose
And desperate proffers of your wanton service?
Have we no more distinction in our birth
And titles? Or d'ye hope we are disarmed
Of strength to punish such an insolence?
Had smiles ta'en such possession of our brow
Thou couldst expect no killing frown for this?
Was our eye grown so tame nothing could quicken it
Into a flame, into a consuming lightning,
When such an object durst appear to vex it?
Thus we could spurn thy saucy head off — but
We pardon it, d'ye hear? we freely pardon it,
To show mercy is above all fault,
And that we are at home Queen of our passions,
Nor shall you suffer under the remembrance,
'Tis now as it had never been, and you keep
